messages.content:
Stage one, analysis.
You are a curriculum consultant specializing in integrating climate resilience into entrepreneurship training in Iraq/KRI. Review this module and provide a structured analysis.

## Module for Review: Design Thinking

### Task 1: Module Summary  
Provide a **2-3 sentence summary** that includes:
- Core learning objectives
- Key activities
- Current participant outcomes

#### Also Identify:
- **Any existing mentions of sustainability or efficiency** (explicit or implicit)
- **Key entrepreneurial decision points** where climate considerations may apply (e.g., resource sourcing, supply chains, energy use)

---

### Task 2: Climate Integration Analysis  
Create a table analyzing opportunities to integrate climate resilience. Use **this format**:

| Location | Current Activity | Suggested Change | Local Context & Reasoning |
|----------|-----------------|------------------|---------------------------|
| [Slide/section] | [Brief description] | [Specific, actionable change] | [Why this matters for Iraq/KRI + business impact] |

**Guidelines:**
- **Location:** Be specific (slide number, page, section).
- **Current Activity:** Focus on what participants actually do.
- **Suggested Change:** Must be **concrete** and **implementable**.
- **Local Context & Reasoning:** Connect to **Iraq/KRI challenges** and **business benefits**.

---

## Module Content:
[[[#
IGNITE
A 2 WEEK-LONG
ENTREPRENEURSHIP PROGRAM
Agenda

9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Introduction to Five One Labs and Ignite
10:05 | Break
10:20 | ‚ÄúYes, and‚Ä¶‚Äù icebreaker 
10:35 | Design thinking overview
10:50 | Design Sprint
11:55 - 12:00 | Wrap up
----

9:00 | Settle in
People arrive
Mingle 
Offer people cookies, fruit, tea, coffee, etc‚Ä¶
Answer questions 

9:15 | Day‚Äôs Intro + Welcome
Introduce yourself and welcome everyone!
Welcome everyone, we are so happy you can join us today for the first day of Ignite! Today is all about getting to know each other, understanding the program, and setting the foundations for the next two weeks as you learn more about the market and your customers needs!
1



LET'S GET TO KNOW EACH OTHER
 Name?
 Where you are from?
 Tell us your idea.
 What‚Äôs your superpower?
10 minutes: Share

Introductions:
Before we get started, I would like to introduce myself and get to know all of you a bit better. Let's quickly go around the room and share:
Your name,
Where you are from,
Tell us a little bit about your idea. 
And finally, if you had a superpower, what would it be (flying, reading minds, shape shifting, etc‚Ä¶)?

The trainers should start first. Then, go around the room so each person can introduce themselves.
2

09:00 am 		Welcome + Introductions!
09:30 am		Five One Labs & Ignite
10:30 am		Design Sprint 
12:00 pm		Group Lunch
01:30 pm		User Research 
04:30 pm		Wrap up
AGENDA
1 minute: Lecture

Agenda: Now that we all know each other a little better, let‚Äôs get into the agenda for the day. 
This morning we will spend some time understanding Five One Labs, the program, and what exactly you will be doing over the two weeks. This will be an opportunity to clarify any questions you still have and give you some insights on what is in store ahead through a design sprint!
Group Lunch: At 12:00 we will take a break and get lunch together. 
This afternoon we will come back and get into user research. This is the first major session we will have. Here we will define our research plan for the next few weeks! Tell us a little bit about your idea, what problem does it solve? Finally, we will wrap up around 4:30!

3

YES, AND‚Ä¶.
15 minutes: Icebreaker 

2 minutes: Explain the activity
Trainers should conduct the ‚ÄúYES, AND‚Ä¶‚Äù Icebreaker
Make teams of about 3-5
State a problem or ask the group for a problem 
For example:
It‚Äôs a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
It is so hot outside, how can I get to and from work without sweating or ever feeling the heat?
¬†
5 minutes: ‚ÄúNo‚Äù technique:
You have 2 minutes to generate different crazy ideas to solve that problem. Generate as many as possible. But there is a rule! When one member in the team says an idea another one must say ‚Äúno!‚Äù and come up with a completely different idea. This goes on and on until the 2 minutes are up. You have to do this quickly, let's see how many crazy ideas we will get.
For example: It‚Äôs a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
Use an umbrella!
No! Build a tunnel to go directly inside!
No! make a waterproof suit that covers your whole body!
No! Build an overpass that my taxi/bus will drop me off under!
No! Have a drone float above my head to prevent water from touching me.
No!.....
[2 minutes pass] Time is done!
Ask them about the different crazy ideas they came up with.
¬†
5 minutes: Now let‚Äôs try ‚Äúyes and‚Äù: 
You have 2 minutes again, and this time someone says an idea, and then someone else in the group must say ‚Äúyes‚Äù, and add a feature to grow the idea to make the idea bigger. Is it clear? Let's do it
For example: It‚Äôs a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
Build a tunnel to go directly inside from where you get dropped off!
Yes! And have heat inside to keep you warm on cold days
Yes! And the heat system is controlled by an app on your phone that you can use to control the temperature where you are walking
Yes! And ‚Ä¶..
Ask them about the different crazy ideas they came up with

3 minutes: Review + recap
Ask them which one did they like and why? (yes and or no method)
Then explain ‚Äúyes and‚Äù is good because it‚Äôs positive, and it feels good when your friends agree with your idea, right? And you can build on top of it to create really good and complete ideas. You can go deeper and come up with things that you normally wouldn‚Äôt have discovered.
‚ÄúNo‚Äù is also good, as it generates a wide variety of ideas. And in real life when you talk about your idea to someone not everybody is positive and will like your idea. Sometimes you have to say no!

Recap: As a rule at Five One Labs, we try to use the ‚Äúyes and‚Äù method. We want to build off and support each other.

4

Design Sprint!
1 minutes: Lecture

Ok great! I hope you had some fun and got to know the people sitting around you a little bit more. 
We are now going to get into the first design thinking session of Ignite, the Design Sprint! We‚Äôll think about creative solutions that are not just effective but also mindful of resources. But first, we will give you a little introduction to the Design curriculum and an overview of the design thinking methodology.
5


Feb. 2, 2020:		      Introduction to Design Thinking
Feb. 2, 2020:		      User Research
Feb. 16, 2020:	      Define the Problem
Feb. 20, 2020:		Creativity and Ideation
 
 

DESIGN THINKING SCHEDULE
April 1
Intro to design thinking
April 1
April 7
April 8
User research
Define the problem
Creativity and ideation
3 minutes: Lecture

Quickly give an overview of the 4 Design sessions they will have over the next two weeks. 
Introduction to Design Thinking: We will focus on giving you a good understanding of design thinking and the human centered design process today through a design sprint. Starting this afternoon, we will talk about applying the Design Thinking methodology to your business.
User Research: We will go into creating a research plan for you to deeply understand your customers and their needs.
Reframe: Define the Problem: We will take all of our research, and clearly define the problem for your different customer types.
Creativity and Ideation: Finally, we will generate solutions to your customers problems. Some of them might be your current ideas, but we hope to generate a wide variety of ideas that could all be potential solutions. 
6

2 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What is design thinking? Why is it useful?
Potential answers:
A way to take a messy problem and turn it into something much more clear and more ordered
A way to enhance your creativity, build stronger, more innovative solutions
To build a deeper understanding of people 
Human centered, iterative, collaborative, experiential 
There is a bias towards action
You should work to embody these mindsets throughout the rest of this sprint

7

increased creativity
stronger solutions
3 minutes: Lecture

The trainer should recap points brought up on the previous slide answering ‚ÄúWhat is design thinking? Why is it useful?‚Äù
A way to take a messy problem and turn it into something much more clear and more ordered
A way to enhance your creativity, build stronger, more innovative solutions
To build a deeper understanding of people 
Human centered, iterative, collaborative, experiential 
There is a bias towards action
You should work to embody these mindsets throughout the rest of this sprint

8

CC, BY-NC-ND, ‚ìí¬†Joe Thorn
Discussion: 5 minutes 

Ask: Take a look at this photo ‚Äì who can tell me what this girl needs? (gather responses and write them on the board separating verbs and nouns without telling the group you are doing so)
Potential answers (nouns):
She needs a book
A ladder
A taller chair
Shoes
Her parents
Etc‚Ä¶ 

Potential answers (verbs)
Be independent
Gain knowledge
Learn information
To explore
Etc‚Ä¶

5 minutes: Recap 
If you define needs as nouns, then there are only so many ways you can solve the problem ‚Äì For example, instead of saying ‚Äòwe need more electricity,‚Äô you could say ‚Äòwe need to reduce energy waste,‚Äô which opens up more creative possibilities.
If you describe the need as a verb, you give yourself exponentially more options ‚Äì For example, if you say ‚Äúshe needs to learn‚Äù, there are so many ways you can do this and you allow for countless possibilities:
Get a teacher
Use a book
Use an online learning app
Watch a video online
Practice something
Etc‚Ä¶ 
During the activity, we‚Äôll ask you to keep this in mind as you‚Äôre getting to know your partner
9

Define a clear problem
Build your product
Find the best ideas
Test and improve
Undertsand your customers
DESIGN THINKING: A NON-LINEAR PROCESS
TEST
PROTOTYPE
IDEATE
DEFINE
EMPATHIZE
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Over the course of this program, you will experience the Design Thinking process and apply it to your businesses. 
The first step is to empathize with your user. Put yourself in their shoes and explore how they are experiencing the problem that your business idea is solving. Speak to customers and listen to their stories. 
After we explore our customers experiences, challenges, and high points, we will reframe that information and define the problem. What is the core challenge that our customers are facing?
Once we have a clearly stated problem statement, we go into ideation. What are all the possible solutions for that customer‚Äôs problem? We want a wide variety of potential solutions. Don‚Äôt be stuck in your idea!
Next, we take a few of these ideas, build them, and test it out! By prototyping and testing frequently, we are able to save time and money while developing a product that the customers really want!

That is the design thinking process. It appears linear, and in some ways it can be. However, keep in mind that it is not intended to be a one way process. You can go back and forth on this depending on your needs.  
Ask: Can someone give me an example of how this might not be a linear process? How might someone using the design thinking methodology move around in a way that is out of order?
Potential answers:
Maybe you are trying to define a clear problem, but you realize you did not gather enough information, go back and get more! Talk to more people
Maybe you finished testing your prototype, you are going to want to bring it back to the customers and listen to how they are experiencing the product. You will continuously go through the process several times. 

Transition: Design is all about being experiential, so let‚Äôs get started!


LET‚ÄôS GO!
< 1 minute: Lecture

Now we are going to do a design sprint and go through the whole Design Thinking process in just 1 hour!
11

2 minutes: Lecture

Frame the activity and put the entrepreneurs in a situation.
So let me start by giving you a problem. I face this problem every day and I‚Äôm sure many of you face it as well. 

Problem: Every morning I wake up exhausted. I dread getting out of my warm bed to go to work in the morning. 

My challenge for all of you is to redesign the morning routine to solve this problem (even if you like the morning, redesign it to make it even better).  There is one caveat here, you are not redesigning the morning routine for yourself, you are designing it for your partner. 

Everyone should now get into pairs. 


12

INTERVIEW
8 minutes: Activity

4 minutes each: Interview Part 1
Learn as much as you can about the other person‚Äôs morning routine
What was their favorite part? What could be improved? 

13

DIG DEEPER
6 minutes: Activity

3 minutes each: Dig Deeper
Time to dig deeper ‚Äì go for emotion
Ask why 5 times
What‚Äôs the underlying reason they do things? 

14

DEFINE
5 minutes: Activity

3 minutes: Capture Findings (alone)
Define needs as verbs 
Pinpoint surprising insights, that you‚Äôll keep in mind as you‚Äôre developing a solution

2 minutes: Reframe (alone)
Write the challenge you are going to address vis a vis your partner
Write out your point of view: ‚Äúmy partner needs to do get to work on time, keeping in mind that she has three kids that she needs to feed and get to school on time as well‚Äù

15

BRAINSTORM
13 minutes: Activity

5 minutes: Brainstorm (alone)
Come up with at least 5 creative ways to solve this problem
Draw, sketch, or write out what you think these solutions would look like
Make sure they‚Äôre all very different from each other
Push yourself to think outside the box. 
Use creative constraints to help your imagination. What it it had to be a physical object, what it it had to be made from recycled materials, what it if had to be made entirely with local materials?
Go for volume ‚Äì generate as many ideas as you can (if you have more than five, write them down anyway)

4 minutes each: Share ideas with your partner
16

BUILD
8 minutes: Activity

Build a prototype!! (alone)
 Offer a diverse range of materials, encourage resource consciousness by providing local, recycled, and green materials.
 Send the entrepreneurs in the other room where prototyping supplies are laid out for them.
 How might this solution fit into the context of your partner‚Äôs life? 
 Improve and build out the concept you talked about
17

FEEDBACK
20 minutes: Activity

6 minutes: Feedback (3 mins each) 
Remember, your idea is not precious, feedback is just a way to learn more
Generate more feedback
Write down how they feel about it
Watch how they use it, misuse it, what mistakes are they making, what doesn‚Äôt make sense, etc
Write down one new idea, one big question from feedback. Could your solution work with fewer resources or less waste?
¬†
10 minutes: Debrief 
How did discussing and gathering feedback from the person change how your final solution looks?
If you had to make it for yourself, would it look the same as it did for your partner?
Who ended up with something their partner really liked? Why? What about it stood out? 
What would you change in your next iteration?
What part was most uncomfortable? What was most natural? 
How was it as a user interacting with the prototype? 

18

DESIGN THINKING: A NON-LINEAR PROCESS
TEST
PROTOTYPE
IDEATE
DEFINE
EMPATHIZE
5 minutes: Wrap up

Briefly explain again how they just went through the whole design thinking process in under an hour
Explain that during Ignite, we will go through the first 3 steps, and then the incubator we will do the last 2 steps
Wrap up for lunch

19

THANK YOU!
Any Questions?]]]

Here's a structured analysis of the **Design Thinking** module with a focus on integrating **climate resilience** into entrepreneurship training in Iraq/KRI.

---

# **Stage One: Analysis of Design Thinking Module**
### **Task 1: Module Summary**

The **Design Thinking** module introduces participants to human-centered innovation through a structured design sprint, encouraging creativity, iteration, and problem-solving. The **core learning objectives** include understanding user needs, defining problems clearly, brainstorming diverse solutions, and rapidly prototyping and testing ideas. **Key activities** involve icebreakers, guided discussions, user research, ideation, prototyping, and feedback sessions. **Current participant outcomes** focus on fostering an entrepreneurial mindset, improving problem-solving skills, and enhancing creativity in developing business solutions.

#### **Mentions of Sustainability or Efficiency**
- Implicitly, the **brainstorming session** encourages solutions using **recycled or local materials**, which touches on sustainability.
- The **design sprint** mentions **resource consciousness**, but it is not a major theme.
- The **feedback session** prompts participants to consider whether their solution could be achieved with **fewer resources or less waste**.

#### **Key Entrepreneurial Decision Points for Climate Integration**
- **User Research**: Understanding how customer needs intersect with sustainability challenges (e.g., energy access, water efficiency).
- **Problem Definition**: Framing challenges in ways that encourage climate-conscious solutions.
- **Ideation & Brainstorming**: Using constraints such as **local materials, circular economy principles, and low-energy solutions**.
- **Prototyping**: Encouraging the use of **sustainable materials and regenerative design**.
- **Testing & Feedback**: Considering long-term environmental impacts and **resource efficiency** in product and business model refinement.

---

### **Task 2: Climate Integration Analysis**

| **Location**       | **Current Activity**                                           | **Suggested Change**                                         | **Local Context & Reasoning**                                      |
|--------------------|------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Brainstorming Session**  | Generating multiple solutions using creative constraints like "What if it had to be made from recycled materials?"  | Expand this to **explicitly require** one climate-resilient solution per participant. Introduce **eco-conscious constraints** such as energy efficiency, water conservation, or circular economy thinking. | Iraq faces **water scarcity, extreme heat, and unreliable energy**. Teaching entrepreneurs to integrate **resource-efficient solutions** at the ideation phase strengthens their ability to develop climate-adaptive businesses. |
| **Prototyping Session** | Participants use available materials to build quick models. | Curate **sustainable prototyping kits** with **biodegradable, upcycled, or regionally sourced materials**. Include an exercise where participants **assess the environmental impact of their prototypes**. | **Plastic waste and poor waste management** are major challenges in Iraq/KRI. Encouraging use of **locally available, eco-friendly materials** fosters a culture of climate-conscious design. |
| **User Research Session** | Participants conduct interviews to understand customer needs. | Add a **climate resilience lens** to user research: Encourage entrepreneurs to ask **how customers are affected by climate change (e.g., rising temperatures, water shortages, unreliable power).** | Many Iraqi businesses struggle with **climate-related disruptions** (e.g., blackouts, floods). Factoring these into product development leads to **more resilient business models**. |
| **Defining the Problem** | Participants identify a clear problem based on research. | Encourage problem definitions to consider **long-term sustainability**. Example: Instead of **‚Äúwe need more energy,‚Äù** define **‚Äúwe need to reduce energy waste‚Äù** or **‚Äúwe need to improve access to off-grid solutions.‚Äù** | Climate-adaptive framing shifts mindsets from **reactive to proactive**, leading to solutions that are **more feasible and impactful in the Iraqi/KRI context**. |
| **Final Wrap-Up** | Summarizing lessons learned from the sprint. | Add a **"sustainability checkpoint"** where teams reflect on **how their solutions impact the environment and local resources**. Provide an **eco-innovation framework** for refining ideas in the incubation phase. | Many **funding opportunities in Iraq/KRI** (e.g., UNDP, IFC, GCF) prioritize **green business models**. Teaching entrepreneurs to think about **sustainability early on** can increase their chances of investment and support. |

---

### **Key Takeaways & Next Steps**
- **Make sustainability explicit**: While resource awareness exists in the module, **climate resilience should be a core lens** rather than an optional constraint.
- **Introduce a sustainability filter**: At each design thinking step, participants should reflect on how their decisions impact **energy, water, waste, and emissions**.
- **Align with Iraq‚Äôs climate realities**: Help entrepreneurs recognize **how climate shocks impact customers and business operations**.
- **Leverage funding opportunities**: Green startups and **climate-conscious businesses are better positioned** to access international support and grants.

Would you like me to suggest **slides or activity modifications** for easier integration? üöÄ

Score:
Using the Stage 1 Analysis, score this module‚Äôs climate resilience integration.

### **Scoring Table**
| Skill Element | Current Score (1-5) | Target Score | Evidence & Gaps | Priority | Feasibility |
|--------------|------------------|--------------|-----------------|---------|-------------|
| [Relevant skill] | [1-5] | [1-5] | [What exists + what's missing] | [High/Medium/Low] | [High/Medium/Low] |

**Relevant Skills to Consider:**
- Business Model Resilience
- Risk Management
- Sustainable Operations
- Technology & Innovation
- Sustainability as Value Proposition
- Impact Measurement
- Green Market Understanding
- Sustainable Product Design
- Systems Thinking
- Problem Framing
- Futures Literacy
- Adaptability

### **Scoring Scale**
- **1 - Not Addressed**: Element is completely absent.
- **2 - Basic Awareness**: Mentioned but not practically applied.
- **3 - Practical Integration**: Includes specific tools or exercises.
- **4 - Strong Application**: Well-integrated with local context.
- **5 - Advanced Integration**: Fully embedded with metrics and real-world applications.

### **Priority Guidelines**
- **High**: Major gap + Core to module + Easy to implement.
- **Medium**: Moderate gap OR Important but harder to implement.
- **Low**: Minor gap OR Not central to module.

### **Feasibility Scale**
- **High**: Quick content tweak (e.g., adding a question).
- **Medium**: Moderate effort (e.g., modifying activities).
- **Low**: Large-scale change (e.g., new training materials).

I've scored the module's **climate resilience integration** using the provided framework. You can review the **detailed scoring table** to identify key gaps and areas for improvement. Let me know if you'd like recommendations on how to close the highest-priority gaps effectively! üöÄ

Using the previous analyses, create specific implementation recommendations focusing on high-priority items.
---

### **Content Changes**
| Location | Current Text | Revised Text | Implementation Notes | Facilitator Action |
|----------|-------------|--------------|---------------------|-------------------|
| Slide X | [Existing content] | [New content] | [Why this matters] | [How to implement] |

---

### **Activity Updates**
| Activity | Current Format | Suggested Modification | Local Context Connection | Facilitator Action |
|----------|---------------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------|

---

### **Essential Resources**
| Resource Type | Current Status | Needed Addition | Purpose |
|--------------|----------------|-----------------|----------|
| [Worksheet/Tool] | [What exists] | [What to add] | [Why it's needed] |

---

### **Guidelines**
- **Focus on highest priority items from Stage 2**.
- **Keep changes minimal but impactful**.
- **Provide specific facilitator actions** (what to do, when, and how).
- **Reference local context where possible**.
- **Only suggest new resources if essential**.

{"name": "climate_resilience_recs", "type": "document", "content": "### **Content Changes**
| Location | Current Text | Revised Text | Implementation Notes | Facilitator Action |
|----------|-------------|--------------|---------------------|-------------------|
| Brainstorming Session | "Use creative constraints to think outside the box." | "Use creative constraints such as requiring one eco-friendly or low-energy solution per idea." | Embeds sustainability into ideation without disrupting existing activity flow. | Instruct participants to incorporate at least one climate-resilient aspect into their ideas. |
| Prototyping Session | "Use available materials to build quick models." | "Use available materials with a focus on sustainable, biodegradable, or recycled options." | Encourages use of locally available, climate-conscious materials. | Provide a selection of green materials and explain their importance. |
| User Research | No mention of sustainability in user interviews. | "Consider asking how climate change impacts your customers and their needs." | Helps integrate real-world climate resilience considerations into business models. | Add a question in user research guidelines about climate challenges faced by customers. |
| Problem Definition | "Define the problem clearly." | "Define the problem while considering environmental and sustainability factors." | Shifts focus toward long-term impact and sustainable framing. | Guide participants to consider sustainability as they refine their problem statements. |
| Final Wrap-Up | No mention of sustainability reflection. | "Reflect on how your solutions impact sustainability, waste, and climate resilience." | Reinforces sustainability thinking throughout the program. | Lead a 5-minute discussion on how sustainability was considered in each project. |

---

### **Activity Updates**
| Activity | Current Format | Suggested Modification | Local Context Connection | Facilitator Action |
|----------|---------------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------|
| Brainstorming | Open-ended ideation with few constraints. | Require at least one idea per participant to focus on sustainability or climate resilience. | Iraq faces energy and water scarcity; embedding sustainability helps create realistic solutions. | Instruct participants to think of at least one "climate-smart" business idea. |
| Prototyping | Any materials can be used. | Provide and prioritize recycled, biodegradable, and local materials. | Waste management is a major issue in Iraq/KRI; using sustainable materials promotes circular economy thinking. | Offer pre-sorted sustainable prototyping kits and explain their importance. |
| User Research | Participants interview customers about needs. | Include a specific section on environmental and climate-related challenges. | Many businesses in Iraq are affected by energy cuts, water shortages, and extreme heat. | Adjust interview templates to include at least one sustainability-related question. |
| Feedback & Iteration | Participants refine ideas based on user feedback. | Ask, "Could this solution work with fewer resources or less waste?" during feedback sessions. | Reduces over-engineering and promotes lean, sustainable innovation. | Guide feedback sessions to include resource efficiency as a key criterion. |

---

### **Essential Resources**
| Resource Type | Current Status | Needed Addition | Purpose |
|--------------|----------------|-----------------|----------|
| User Research Guide | No climate-focused questions. | Add 2-3 questions on climate risks and environmental impact. | Helps entrepreneurs factor in climate realities when designing products. |
| Prototyping Materials | Generic materials. | Sustainable options like biodegradable plastics, recycled paper, and local materials. | Encourages conscious material choices in product design. |
| Design Thinking Worksheets | No sustainability prompts. | Add a section on evaluating sustainability impact of ideas. | Ensures climate considerations are part of early-stage design thinking. |

---

### **Guidelines**
- **Focus on highest priority items from Stage 2**.
- **Keep changes minimal but impactful**.
- **Provide specific facilitator actions** (what to do, when, and how).
- **Reference local context where possible**.
- **Only suggest new resources if essential**."}
